references:
We consider an FL system in a HieIoT network consisting of a set ℳ≜{v1,…,vM}≜ℳsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑀{\cal M}\triangleq\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{M}\} of M𝑀M RCs (i.e., clients registered at the FL platform) and a set of 𝒩≜{v1,…,vN}≜𝒩subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑁{\cal N}\triangleq\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{N}\} of N𝑁N UnRCs.
The set of all RCs and UnRCs is denoted by 𝒱≜{v1,v2,…,v|𝒱|}≜𝒱subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2…subscript𝑣𝒱{\cal V}\triangleq\{v_{1},v_{2},\ldots,v_{|{\cal V}|}\} and |𝒱|=M+N.𝒱𝑀𝑁|{\cal V}|=M+N.
The FL server first broadcast the information of a FL job to all RCs, but it does not have access to the information of UnRCs.
Moreover, the trust among clients can be established through SIoTs such as WeChat, Twitter, and Facebook, etc., so the trust remains unchanged for a long time.
In addition, without loss of generality, we assume that for each UnRC vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N}, there exists at least one RC (vm∈ℳsubscript𝑣𝑚ℳv_{m}\in{\cal M}) having a social relationship with the UnRC.
This assumption is reasonable because if there is no trust value from any RC to UnRC vn∈𝒩subscript𝑣𝑛𝒩v_{n}\in{\cal N}, then vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} will not be recommended by RCs (i.e., it will not participate in any task).
In this context, we first remove this type of UnRCs when implementing LRef-FedCS.
Denote by 𝑾=[wm,n]∈ℝM×N𝑾delimited-[]subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛superscriptℝ𝑀𝑁{\boldsymbol{W}}=[w_{m,n}]\in{\mathbb{R}}^{M\times N} the trust matrix with entries wm,n∈[0,1]subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛01w_{m,n}\in[0,1] representing the trust value between RC vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} and UnRC vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n}, where wm,n=0subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛0w_{m,n}=0 means vmsubscript𝑣𝑚v_{m} and vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} are strangers and wm,n∈(0,1]subscript𝑤𝑚𝑛01w_{m,n}\in(0,1] otherwise.
The key notation definitions are summarized in Table I.

Based on the communication phase described in Section V.A, it is necessary to carefully configure the simulation parameters.
First, we consider a wireless FL with carrier frequency 2.3​ GHz2.3 GHz2.3\text{~{}GHz} and bandwidth 0.2​ MHz.0.2 MHz0.2\text{~{}MHz}.
We set the path loss exponents for each individual link and the path loss at the reference distance 1​ m1 m1\text{~{}m} to be 333 and 303030 dBm, respectively, and adopt Rayleigh fading to reproduce multipath effects [27].
We assume that perfect channel information is known at the receivers pilot signals [27].
Throughout the simulations, unless otherwise specified, we adopt the parameters reported in Table II, where, for simplicity, each UnRC is assumed to have the same long-term QoS requirement, i.e., Rminc2csuperscriptsubscript𝑅c2cR_{\min}^{\text{c2c}}, and each potential participant is also assumed to have the same computation time constraint in one local iteration, i.e., TmaxcmpsuperscriptsubscriptTcmp\text{T}_{\max}^{\text{cmp}}.
Moreover, all the RCs are assumed to have the same CPU frequency fm=frcsubscript𝑓𝑚subscript𝑓rcf_{m}=f_{\text{rc}} and transmit power budget pmmax=prcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑝rcp_{m}^{\max}=p_{\text{rc}}^{\max}.
Likewise, the same CPU frequency fn=furcsubscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑓urcf_{n}=f_{\text{urc}} and the maximum transmit power pnmax=purcmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑝urcp_{n}^{\max}=p_{\text{urc}}^{\max} are imposed for all UnRCs.
In addition, we set λt=1/6superscript𝜆𝑡16\lambda^{t}={1}/{6} and λe=5/6superscript𝜆𝑒56\lambda^{e}={5}/{6}.
